Ingest_LDD.name: Geometry Dictionary Full
Ingest_LDD.comment: Version 0.6.0.0 Revised by M. Gordon. Combined building blocks, orbiter and lander into one dictionary Changed version number to indicate development version Written using Ingest_LDD Revised organization - within definitions of attributes and classes, the contents are grouped by function rather than alphabetically. Removed defining classes (Units_of_Any, Units_of_Vector_components) to assign units. Added additional attributes to compensate for the removal in previous line. Moved spacecraft specfic vectors and distances to geomo dictionary. Version 0.6.1.0 Revised by M. Gordon. Replaced naif_name with body_spice_name and frame_spice_name Replaced naif_id with body_spice_id and frame_spice_id Renamed the quaternion components from [q1,q2,q3,q4] to [Qcos, Qsin1, Qsin2, Qsin3]; order depends on quaternion type. Revised definitions for the two quaternion types, including incorporating the new component names. Modified the Coordinate_System class. The coordinate system constructs are typically used for orbiter/flyby spacecraft while coordinate space constructs are typically used for lander/rover missions. Added Internal_Reference to the Camera_Model_Parameters class. Added *_Vector_Extended_Base which begin with corresponding *_Vector_Base and add light_time_correction_applied attribute and Coordinate_System classes. All generic and specific orbiter vectors modified to derive from *_Vector_Extended_Base classes. Changed the class SPICE_Kernel_Name to SPICE_Kernel_Identification. Changed the attribute spice_kernel_name to local_spice_kernel_name.

DD_Attribute.name: geometry_reference_time
DD_Attribute.definition: geometry_reference_time is the time at which each of the values in the containing class is correct. Note: [mkg] I'm placing this as a required field once in the label. There are alternative approaches: 1) place in each subclass in stead of one global value 2) require a global value with an optional entry in subclasses. Value at the lowest level takes precedence over the global value.

DD_Attribute.name: coordinate_system_type
DD_Attribute.definition: The coordinate_system_type distinguishes between options such as rectangular, spherical, planetocentric, etc.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: The coordinate system uses rectangular coordinates.

The coordinate system uses azimuth-elevation coordinates. Azimuth: angle from +X axis to projection of position vector on x-y plane increases in clockwise direction (-180 to +180). Elevation: angle between position vector and x-y plane (-90 to +90).

The coordinate system uses spherical coordinates. Longitude: angle from +X axis to projection of position vector on X-Y plane increases in clockwise direction (0 to 360). Colatitude: angle between +Z axis and position vector (0 to 180).

The coordinate system uses planetocentric coordinates. Planetocentric longitude increases positively eastward (-180 to +180). Planetocentric latitude increases positively northward (-90 to +90). For planets and their satellites the +Z axis (+90 latitude) always points to the north side of the invariable plane (the plane whose normal vector is the angular momentum vector of the solar system). For dwarf planets, asteroids and comets the IAU defines their positive pole such that their spin is in the right hand sense about their positive pole. The positive pole may point above or below the invariable plane of the solar system. This revision by the IAU Working Group (2006) inverts what had been the direction of the north pole for Pluto, Charon and Ida.

The coordinate system uses planetodetic coordinates. For planets and their satellites the +Z axis (+90 latitude) always points to the north side of the invariable plane (the plane whose normal vector is the angular momentum vector of the solar system). Planetodetic longitude increases positively eastward (-180 to +180). Planetodetic latitude is tied to a reference ellipsoid. For a point, P, on a reference ellipsoid, angle measured from X-Y plane to the surface normal at the point of interest. For other points, equals latitude at the nearest point on the reference ellipsoid. Increases positively northward (-90 to +90).

The coordinate system uses planetographic coordinates. For planet and satellite planetographic coordinate systems: Planetographic longitude is usually defined such that the sub-observer longitude increases with time as seen by a distant, fixed observer (0 to 360). The earth, moon and sun are exceptions; planetographic longitude is positive east by default (0 to 360). Planetographic latitude is planetodetic latitude (-90 to +90). For dwarf planets, asteroids and comets: there are multiple, inconsistent standards. Currently, for these objects, PDS permits planetographic coordinates to be provided in addition to, not in lieu of, either planetocentric or planetodetic coordinates.

DD_Attribute.name: coordinate_system_time
DD_Attribute.definition: The coordinate_system_time provides the instantiation time for the coordinate system.

DD_Attribute.name: body_spice_id
DD_Attribute.definition: The body_spice_id attribute is a NAIF-recognized numeric identifier for a physical object (spacecraft, planet, instrument transmitter, system barycenter, etc., associated with the data.

DD_Attribute.name: frame_spice_id
DD_Attribute.definition: The frame_spice_id attribute is a NAIF-recognized numeric identifier for a reference frame associated with the data.

DD_Attribute.name: body_spice_name
DD_Attribute.definition: The body_spice_name attribute is a NAIF-recognized string identifier for a physical object (spacecraft, planet, instrument transmitter, system barycenter, etc., associated with the data.

DD_Attribute.name: frame_spice_name
DD_Attribute.definition: The frame_spice_name attribute is a NAIF-recognized string identifier for a reference frame associated with the data.

DD_Attribute.name: reference_location
DD_Attribute.definition: The reference_location indicates the position to which values in the containing class apply. If the reference location is on a target, the target is the one specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: Values were determined for the point where the boresight vector intersects the designated target.
Values were determined for the subspacecraft point on the designated target.
Values were determined for the center of the designated target.

DD_Attribute.name: reference_pixel_location
DD_Attribute.definition: The reference_pixel_location indicates the position of the pixel to which values in the containing class apply.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: Values were determined for the intersection of a vector through the center of the field of view with the specified target.
Values were determined for the intersection of a vector through the upper left corner of the field of view with the specified target.
Values were determined for the intersection of a vector through the lower left corner of the field of view with the specified target.
Values were determined for the intersection of a vector through the upper right corner of the field of view with the specified target.
Values were determined for the intersection of a vector through the lower right corner of the field of view with the specified target.

DD_Attribute.name: local_spice_kernel_name
DD_Attribute.definition: The local_spice_kernel_name attribute is the mission designated file name for a SPICE kernel.

DD_Attribute.name: vertical_coordinate_pixel
DD_Attribute.definition: vertical_coordinate_pixel (line) is the vertical coordinate of a specific pixel.

DD_Attribute.name: horizontal_coordinate_pixel
DD_Attribute.definition: horizontal_coordinate_pixel (sample) is the horizontal coordinate of a specific pixel.

DD_Attribute.name: north_azimuth
DD_Attribute.definition: Assuming the image is displayed as defined by the Display_Direction class, the north_azimuth attribute provides the value of the angle between a line from the image center to the north pole and a reference line in the image plane. The reference line is a horizontal line from the image center to the middle right edge of the image. This angle increases in a clockwise direction.

DD_Attribute.name: east_azimuth
DD_Attribute.definition: Assuming the image is displayed as defined by the Display_Direction class, the east_azimuth attribute provides the value of the angle between a line from the image center to the east and a reference line in the image plane. The reference line is a horizontal line from the image center to the middle right edge of the image. This angle increases in a clockwise direction.

DD_Attribute.name: right_ascension_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The right_ascension_angle attribute provides the value of right ascension (RA) as an angle. Right ascension is measured from the vernal equinox or the first point of Aries, which is the place on the celestial sphere where the Sun crosses the celestial equator from south to north at the March equinox. Right ascension is measured continuously in a full circle from that equinox towards the east. Right ascension is used in conjunction with the declination attribute to specify a point on the sky.Note Right Ascension is normally given in hour angles in which case the appropriate attribute is right_ascension_hour_angle.

DD_Attribute.name: right_ascension_hour_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The right_ascension_hour_angle attribute provides the value of right ascension (RA) as in terms of hour angles (hh:mm:ss.sss...). Right ascension is measured from the vernal equinox or the first point of Aries, which is the place on the celestial sphere where the Sun crosses the celestial equator from south to north at the March equinox. Right ascension is measured continuously in a full circle from that equinox towards the east. Right ascension is used in conjunction with the declination attribute to specify a point on the sky.

DD_Attribute.name: declination_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The declination_angle (Dec) attribute provides the value of an angle on the celestial sphere, measured north from the celestial equator to the point in question. (For points south of the celestial equator, negative values are used.) declination is used in conjunction with the right_ascension attribute to specify a point on the sky.

DD_Attribute.name: celestial_north_clock_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The celestial_north_clock_angle attribute specifies the direction of celestial north at the center of an image. It is measured from the 'upward' direction, clockwise to the direction toward celestial north, assuming the image is displayed as defined by the Display_Direction class..

DD_Attribute.name: ecliptic_north_clock_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The ecliptic_north_clock_angle attribute specifies the direction of ecliptic north at the center of an image. It is measured from the 'upward' direction, clockwise to the direction toward ecliptic north, assuming the image is displayed as defined by the Display_Direction class..

DD_Attribute.name: sun_direction_clock_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The sun_direction_clock_angle attribute specifies the direction of the sun as an angle measured from a line 'upward' from the center of the field of view, clockwise to the direction toward sun, assuming the image is displayed as defined by the Display_Direction class..

DD_Attribute.name: body_positive_pole_clock_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The body_positive_pole_clock_angle element specifies the direction of a body's rotation axis in an image. This attribute typically is used when specifying body center coorinates for dwarf planets, minor planets, their satellites, and for comets. It is measured from the 'upward' direction in the image, clockwise to the direction of the positive rotational pole as projected into the image plane, assuming the image is displayed as defined by the Display_Direction class. The positive pole is used to define the poles of dwarf planets, minor planets, their satellites, and comets according to the right-hand rule. "positive" is the pole toward which the thumb points when the fingers are curled in the body's direction of rotation.

DD_Attribute.name: target_positive_pole_clock_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The target_positive_pole_clock_angle element specifies the direction of the target body's rotation axis in an image. It is measured from the 'upward' direction in the image, clockwise to the direction of the positive rotational pole as projected into the image plane, assuming the image is displayed as defined by the Display_Direction class. The positive pole is used to define the poles of dwarf planets, minor planets, their satellites, and comets according to the right-hand rule. "positive" is the pole toward which the thumb points when the fingers are curled in the body's direction of rotation.

DD_Attribute.name: target_north_pole_clock_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The target_north_pole_clock_angle element specifies the direction of the target body's rotation axis in an image. It is measured from the 'upward' direction in the image, clockwise to the direction of the northern rotational pole as projected into the image plane, assuming the image is displayed as defined by the Display_Direction class. The north pole of a planet or any of its satellites in the solar system is the pole of the rotation axis that is in the same celestial hemisphere relative to the invariable plane of the solar system as Earth's North pole.

DD_Attribute.name: central_body_north_pole_clock_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The central_body_north_pole_clock_angle element specifies the direction of the central body's (e.g., planet's)rotation axis in an image. It is measured from the 'upward' direction in the image, clockwise to the direction of the northern rotational pole as projected into the image plane, assuming the image is displayed as defined by the Display_Direction class. The north pole of a planet or any of its satellites in the solar system is the pole of the rotation axis that is in the same celestial hemisphere relative to the invariable plane of the solar system as Earth's North pole.

DD_Attribute.name: qcos
DD_Attribute.definition: One of the four components of a quaternion (Qcos, Qsin1, Qsin2, Qsin3). The order used in a quaternion depends on the 'style' of the quaternion.

DD_Attribute.name: qsin1
DD_Attribute.definition: One of the four components of a quaternion (Qcos, Qsin1, Qsin2, Qsin3). The order used in a quaternion depends on the 'style' of the quaternion.

DD_Attribute.name: qsin2
DD_Attribute.definition: One of the four components of a quaternion (Qcos, Qsin1, Qsin2, Qsin3). The order used in a quaternion depends on the 'style' of the quaternion.

DD_Attribute.name: qsin3
DD_Attribute.definition: One of the four components of a quaternion (Qcos, Qsin1, Qsin2, Qsin3). The order used in a quaternion depends on the 'style' of the quaternion.

DD_Attribute.name: horizontal_pixel_size_angular
DD_Attribute.definition: The horizontal_pixel_size_angular provides the angular measure of the horizontal field of view of a single pixel. This is equivalent to the PDS3 element horizontal_pixel_field_of_view.

DD_Attribute.name: vertical_pixel_size_angular
DD_Attribute.definition: The vertical_pixel_size_angular provides the angular measure of the vertical field of view of a single pixel. This is equivalent to the PDS3 element vertical_pixel_field_of_view.

DD_Attribute.name: horizontal_pixel_size_projected
DD_Attribute.definition: The horizontal_pixel_size_projected provides the the size of the horizontal field of view of a single pixel projected onto the target specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class. Analogus to PDS3 keyword PIXEL_SCALE

DD_Attribute.name: vertical_pixel_size_projected
DD_Attribute.definition: The vertical_pixel_size_projected provides the size of the vertical field of view of a single pixel projected onto the target specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class. Analogus to PDS3 keyword PIXEL_SCALE

DD_Attribute.name: horizontal_pixel_scale_factor
DD_Attribute.definition: The horizontal_pixel_scale_factor provides a scaling factor which when multiplied by the distance to a point of the surface of the target identified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class gives the horizontal size of a pixel projected on the target in units of length (e.g., kilometers).

DD_Attribute.name: vertical_pixel_scale_factor
DD_Attribute.definition: The vertical_pixel_scale_factor provides a scaling factor which when multiplied by the distance to a point of the surface of the target identified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class gives the vertical sizes of a pixel projected on the target in units of length (e.g., kilometers).

DD_Attribute.name: pixel_latitude
DD_Attribute.definition: The pixel_latitude attribute gives the value of the planetocentric latitude on the target of the projection of a specified pixel.

DD_Attribute.name: pixel_longitude
DD_Attribute.definition: The pixel_longitude attribute gives the value of the planetocentric longitude on the target of the projection of a specified pixel.

DD_Attribute.name: subsolar_azimuth
DD_Attribute.definition: The subsolar_azimuth attribute provides the value of the angle between the line from the center of an image to the subsolar point on the target and a horizontal reference line (in the image plane) extending from the image center to the middle right edge of the image. The values of this angle increase in a clockwise direction.

DD_Attribute.name: subsolar_latitude
DD_Attribute.definition: The subsolar_latitude attribute gives the value of the planetocentric latitude at the subsolar point on the target.

DD_Attribute.name: subsolar_longitude
DD_Attribute.definition: The subsolar_longitude attribute gives the value of the planetocentric longitude at the subsolar point on the target.

DD_Attribute.name: subspacecraft_azimuth
DD_Attribute.definition: The subspacecraft_azimuth attribute provides the value of the angle between the line from the center of an image to the subspacecraft point on the target and a horizontal reference line (in the image plane) extending from the image center to the middle right edge of the image. The values of this angle increase in a clockwise direction.

DD_Attribute.name: subspacecraft_latitude
DD_Attribute.definition: The subspacecraft_latitude attribute gives the value of the planetocentric latitude at the subspacecraft point on the target.

DD_Attribute.name: subspacecraft_longitude
DD_Attribute.definition: The subspacecraft_longitude attribute gives the value of the planetocentric longitude at the subspacecraft point on the target.

DD_Attribute.name: calibration_source_id
DD_Attribute.definition: The calibration_source_id is used to identify the source used in calibrating the instrument.

DD_Attribute.name: c0
DD_Attribute.definition: The first coefficient of a polynomial.

DD_Attribute.name: c1
DD_Attribute.definition: The second coefficient of a polynomial.

DD_Attribute.name: c2
DD_Attribute.definition: The third coefficient of a polynomial.

DD_Attribute.name: device_id
DD_Attribute.definition: TBD.

DD_Attribute.name: device_mode
DD_Attribute.definition: TBD.

DD_Attribute.name: device_name
DD_Attribute.definition: TBD.

DD_Attribute.name: model_desc_file_name
DD_Attribute.definition: TBD.

DD_Attribute.name: model_type
DD_Attribute.definition: TBD.

DD_Attribute.name: solution_id
DD_Attribute.definition: TBD.

DD_Attribute.name: index_sequence_number
DD_Attribute.definition: TBD.

DD_Attribute.name: index_name
DD_Attribute.definition: TBD.

DD_Attribute.name: index_id
DD_Attribute.definition: TBD.

DD_Attribute.name: index_value_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: TBD.

DD_Attribute.name: index_value_length
DD_Attribute.definition: TBD.

DD_Attribute.name: index_value_no_units
DD_Attribute.definition: TBD.

DD_Attribute.name: index_value_string
DD_Attribute.definition: TBD.

DD_Attribute.name: index_value_temperature
DD_Attribute.definition: TBD.

DD_Attribute.name: illumination_range_designation
DD_Attribute.definition: The illumination_range_designation indicates whether values given in the Illumination_Range_Values class apply to the entire field of view, or the portion within the field of view of the target specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: Values were determined for the field of view.
Values were determined for the portion within the field of view of the target specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class.

DD_Attribute.name: emission_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The emission_angle element provides the value of the angle between the surface normal vector at the intercept point and a vector from the intercept point to the spacecraft. The emission_angle varies from 0 degrees when the spacecraft is viewing the subspacecraft point (nadir viewing) to 90 degrees when the intercept is tangent to the surface of the target body. Thus, higher values of emission_angle indicate more oblique viewing of the target. Values in the range of 90 to 180 degrees are possible for ring data.

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_emission_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The minimum_emission_angle element provides the smallest value for the emission angle in the observation.

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_emission_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The maximum_emission_angle element provides the largest value for the emission angle in the observation.

DD_Attribute.name: incidence_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The incidence_angle element provides a measure of the lighting condition at the intercept point. Incidence angle is the angle between the local vertical at the intercept point (surface) and a vector from the intercept point to the sun. The incidence_angle varies from 0 degrees when the intercept point coincides with the subsolar point to 90 degrees when the intercept point is at the terminator (i.e., in the shadowed or dark portion of the target body). Thus, higher values of incidence_angle indicate the existence of a greater number of surface shadows. Note: In PDS labels for Magellan's altimetry and radiometry products, and for Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter Mini-RF products, incidence_angle is defined as the value of the angle between the local vertical and the spacecraft direction. For Magellan this is measured at the center of the radiometer footprint at rad_spacecraft_epoch_time.

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_incidence_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The minimum_incidence_angle element provides the smallest value for the incidence angle in the observation.

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_incidence_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The maximum_incidence_angle element provides the largest value for the incidence angle in the observation.

DD_Attribute.name: phase_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The phase_angle element provides a measure of the relationship between the instrument viewing position and incident illumination (such as solar light). Phase_angle is measured at the target; it is the angle between a vector to the illumination source and a vector to the instrument. If not specfied, the target is assumed to be at the center of the instrument field of view. If illumination is from behind the instrument, phase_angle will be small.

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_phase_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The minimum_phase_angle element provides the smallest value for the phase angle in the observation.

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_phase_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The maximum_phase_angle element provides the largest value for the phase angle in the observation.

DD_Attribute.name: solar_elongation
DD_Attribute.definition: [mkg: PDS3 does not give a value range; I do, so make sure I haven't missed something.] The solar_elongation element gives the angle between the line of sight of observation and the direction of the Sun. Note: For IRAS: The line of sight of observation is the boresight of the telescope as measured by the satellite sun sensor.

DD_Attribute.name: distance
DD_Attribute.definition: The distance attribute provides the scaler distance between to objects or points.

DD_Attribute.name: target_geocentric_distance
DD_Attribute.definition: The target_geocentric_distance attribute provides the scaler distance between the center of the target and the center of the Earth.

DD_Attribute.name: target_heliocentric_distance
DD_Attribute.definition: The target_heliocentric_distance attribute provides the scaler distance between the center of the target and the center of the Sun.

DD_Attribute.name: target_ssb_distance
DD_Attribute.definition: The target_ssb_distance attribute provides the scaler distance between the center of the target and the Solar System Barycenter.

DD_Attribute.name: spacecraft_to_target_center_distance
DD_Attribute.definition: The spacecraft_to_target_center_distance attribute provides the scaler distance between the spacecraft and the center of the target specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class.

DD_Attribute.name: spacecraft_to_target_boresight_intercept_distance
DD_Attribute.definition: The spacecraft_to_target_boresight_intercept_distance attribute provides the scaler distance between the spacecraft and the boresight vector intercept point on the surface of the target specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class.

DD_Attribute.name: spacecraft_to_target_subspacecraft_distance
DD_Attribute.definition: The spacecraft_to_target_subspacecraft_distance attribute provides the scaler distance between the spacecraft and the subspacecraft point on the surface of the target specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class.

DD_Attribute.name: spacecraft_to_central_body_distance
DD_Attribute.definition: The spacecraft_to_central_body_distance attribute provides the scaler distance between the spacecraft and the center of the central body (e.g., the center of Mars when opperating in the Mars system).

DD_Attribute.name: spacecraft_geocentric_distance
DD_Attribute.definition: The spacecraft_geocentric_distance attribute provides the scaler distance between the spacecraft and the center of Earth.

DD_Attribute.name: spacecraft_heliocentric_distance
DD_Attribute.definition: The spacecraft_heliocentric_distance attribute provides the scaler distance between the spacecraft and the center of the Sun.

DD_Attribute.name: light_time_correction_applied
DD_Attribute.definition: The light_time_correction_applied indicates whether or not light travel time correction and stellar aberration correction were used when calculating the values in the enclosing class. The attribute is nillable with nill_reason = unknown, but only for migrated data. Note: generally, received light travel time is calculated unless a transmitter (e.g., radar, radio)was involved in which the calculation typically is transmitted light time.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: Neither light travel time nor stellar aberration was used when calculating the values in the enclosing class.
Received light travel time, but not stellar aberration was used when calculating the values in the enclosing class.
Received light travel time and stellar aberration were used when calculating the values in the enclosing class.
Transmitted light travel time, but not stellar aberration was used when calculating the values in the enclosing class.
Transmitted light travel time and stellar aberration were used when calculating the values in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: x_position
DD_Attribute.definition: The x component of a Cartisean position vector.

DD_Attribute.name: y_position
DD_Attribute.definition: The y component of a Cartisean position vector.

DD_Attribute.name: z_position
DD_Attribute.definition: The z component of a Cartisean position vector.

DD_Attribute.name: x_velocity
DD_Attribute.definition: The x component of a Cartisean velocity vector.

DD_Attribute.name: y_velocity
DD_Attribute.definition: The y component of a Cartisean velocity vector.

DD_Attribute.name: z_velocity
DD_Attribute.definition: The z component of a Cartisean velocity vector.

DD_Attribute.name: x_acceleration
DD_Attribute.definition: The x component of a Cartisean acceleration vector.

DD_Attribute.name: y_acceleration
DD_Attribute.definition: The y component of a Cartisean acceleration vector.

DD_Attribute.name: z_acceleration
DD_Attribute.definition: The z component of a Cartisean acceleration vector.

DD_Attribute.name: x_pixel
DD_Attribute.definition: The x component of a Cartisean pixel vector; typically used in cameral models.

DD_Attribute.name: y_pixel
DD_Attribute.definition: The y component of a Cartisean pixel vector; typically used in cameral models.

DD_Attribute.name: z_pixel
DD_Attribute.definition: The z component of a Cartisean pixel vector; typically used in cameral models.

DD_Attribute.name: x_no_units
DD_Attribute.definition: The x component of a Cartisean vector which has no units.

DD_Attribute.name: y_no_units
DD_Attribute.definition: The y component of a Cartisean vector which has no units.

DD_Attribute.name: z_no_units
DD_Attribute.definition: The z component of a Cartisean vector which has no units.

DD_Attribute.name: x_unit
DD_Attribute.definition: The x component of a unit Cartisean vector.

DD_Attribute.name: y_unit
DD_Attribute.definition: The y component of a unit Cartisean vector.

DD_Attribute.name: z_unit
DD_Attribute.definition: The z component of a unit Cartisean vector.

DD_Attribute.name: radius_position
DD_Attribute.definition: The radial component of a spherical or cylindrical position vector (e.g., the radius coordinate in Planetocentric coordinates).

DD_Attribute.name: longitude_position
DD_Attribute.definition: The longitudinal component of a Planetocentric position vector. Planetocentric longitude is measured from the IAU approved prime meridian for the body and increases toward the east.

DD_Attribute.name: latitude_position
DD_Attribute.definition: The latitude component of a Planetocentric position vector. Planetocentric latitude is the angle between the equator plane and a vector connecting the point of interest and the origin of the coordinate system. Latitudes are defined to be positive in the northern (as defined by the IAU) hemisphere.

DD_Attribute.name: radial_velocity
DD_Attribute.definition: The radial component of a spherical or cylindrical velocity vector.

DD_Attribute.name: longitude_velocity
DD_Attribute.definition: The longitudinal component of a Planetocentric velocity vector. Planetocentric longitude is measured from the IAU approved prime meridian for the body and increases toward the east.

DD_Attribute.name: latitude_velocity
DD_Attribute.definition: The latitude component of a Planetocentric velocity vector. Planetocentric latitude is the angle between the equator plane and a vector connecting the point of interest and the origin of the coordinate system. Latitudes are defined to be positive in the northern (as defined by the IAU) hemisphere.

DD_Class.name: Geometry_Identification_Base
DD_Class.definition: The Geometry_Identification_Base class provides multiple attributes which can be used to identify a physical object (spacecraft, planet instrument, transmitter, system barycenter, etc.) or a reference frame. At least one must be used.

DD_Class.name: Central_Body_Identification
DD_Class.definition: The Central_Body_Identification class uniquely identifies the body associated with the central body associated with an observation (for ex., a planet in the solar system).

DD_Class.name: Coordinate_System_Origin_Identification
DD_Class.definition: The Coordinate_System_Origin_Identification class provides the origin of a coordinate system using body_spice_name (or _id).

DD_Class.name: Observer_Identification
DD_Class.definition: Within the Geometry dictionary context, an "Observer" is the body on the "from" end of a vector, quaternion, or other translation through space.

DD_Class.name: Reference_Frame_Identification
DD_Class.definition: The Reference_Frame_Identification class is a base class for identifying reference frames. These are frames in the NAIF sense, i.e., three orthogonal axes with a specified orientation, but without a fixed origin.

DD_Class.name: Target_Identification
DD_Class.definition: Within the Geometry dictionary context, a "Target" is the body on the "to" end of a vector, quaternion, or other translation through space.

DD_Class.name: Coordinate_Space_Index
DD_Class.definition: TBD

DD_Class.name: Coordinate_Space_Identification
DD_Class.definition: The Coordinate_Space_Identification class uniquely identifies a coordinate space (i.e., reference frame + position) with respect to which the values of the attributes in the containing class are defined.

DD_Class.name: Reference_Coordinate_Space
DD_Class.definition: TBD

DD_Class.name: Coordinate_System
DD_Class.definition: The Coordinate_System class fully describes a coordinate system. It identifes the reference frame, coordinate system type (cartesian, planetocentric, etc.), origin, and the instantiation time of the system.

DD_Class.name: Polynomial_Coefficients_1
DD_Class.definition: The Polynomial_Coefficients_1 class provides a one polynomial coefficient.

DD_Class.name: Polynomial_Coefficients_2
DD_Class.definition: The Polynomial_Coefficients_2 class provides two polynomial coefficients.

DD_Class.name: Polynomial_Coefficients_3
DD_Class.definition: The Polynomial_Coefficients_3 class provides three polynomial coefficients.

DD_Class.name: Quaternion_SPICE_Style
DD_Class.definition: The Quaternion_SPICE_Style class provides a quaternion that describes the transformation information between two reference frames. For a SPICE style quaternion the order of the four components is (Qcos, Qsin1, Qsin2, Qsin3). See NAIF SPICE documentation for additional details.

DD_Class.name: Quaternion__non_SPICE_Style
DD_Class.definition: The Quaternion__non_SPICE_Style class provides a quaternion that describes the transformation information between two reference frames. For a non-SPICE style quaternion the order of the four components is (Qsin1, Qsin2, Qsin3, Qcos). See NAIF SPICE documentation for additional details.

DD_Class.name: SPICE_Kernel_Identification
DD_Class.definition: The SPICE_Kernel_Identification class includes the SPICE kernel type and provides three alternatives for identifying the product: LIDVID using Internal_Reference (this is the preferred option), the official file name of the kernel file as assigned by the PDS NAIF node, or the local file name assigned by the mission pending the official NAIF designation. Local file names must be unique, and one-to-one associations between the local file name and the NAIF file name or LIDVID must be maintained.

DD_Class.name: SPICE_Kernel_Files
DD_Class.definition: The SPICE_Kernel_Files class provides references to the SPICE files used when calculating geometric values. The preferred reference mechanism is to give the LIDVID for each SPICE file. If a LIDVID has not been asigned, then the file name of that file is used.

DD_Class.name: List_Index_Angle
DD_Class.definition: Used when the list values are angles.

DD_Class.name: List_Index_Length
DD_Class.definition: Used when the list values are lengths.

DD_Class.name: List_Index_No_Units
DD_Class.definition: Used when the list values have no units.

DD_Class.name: List_Index_Text
DD_Class.definition: Used when the list values are strings.

DD_Class.name: List_Index_Temperature
DD_Class.definition: Used when the list values are temperatures.

DD_Class.name: Reference_Pixel
DD_Class.definition: The Reference_Pixel class provides the pixel coordinates, line and sample, to which values in the containing class apply. Integer values indicate the center of the pixel. Sub-pixel values are permitted. For pixel_sample, the leading edge (left edge for sample increasing to the right) has a value 0.5 less than the integer value at the center, and the value for the trailing edge is the center integer value + 0.5. For pixel_line, the leading and trailing edges (top and bottom respectively for line increasing downward) again are -0.5 and +0.5 with respect to the center integer value.

DD_Class.name: Object_Orientation_North_East
DD_Class.definition: The Object_Orientation_North_East class provides the parameters needed to describe the orientation of an external coordinate system relative to the image coordinate frame as described by the Image_Orientation class.

DD_Class.name: Object_Orientation_RA_Dec
DD_Class.definition: The Object_Orientation_RA_Dec class provides the parameters needed to describe the orientation of the celestial reference frame relative to the image coordinate frame as described by the Image_Orientation class.

DD_Class.name: Object_Orientation_Clock_Angles
DD_Class.definition: The Object_Orientation_Clock_Angles class provides the clock angles measure from the center of the field of view to celestial and ecliptic north, and to the sun.

DD_Class.name: List_Index_Base
DD_Class.definition: The List_Index class is a private (i.e., abstract) class designed to enable the use of indexed lists. The minimum requirement is at least one of sequence number, name or "id", plus the set of values themselves.

DD_Class.name: Pixel_Size_Projected
DD_Class.definition: The Pixel_Size_Projected class gives the size, in units of length (e.g., kilometers) of the projection of a pixel onto the surface of the target which is specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class. The reference_location attribute is used to identify the specific point on the target.

DD_Class.name: Illumination_Single_Values
DD_Class.definition: The Illumination_Single_Values class contains attributes providing illumination parameters at a single location in the field of view. If reference_location is used, and indicates a point on a target, the target must be the one specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class.

DD_Class.name: Illumination_FOV_Range_Values
DD_Class.definition: The Illumination_FOV_Range_Values class contains attributes providing illumination parameters as minimum/maximum pairs for either the field of view or the portion in the FoV of the target specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class.

DD_Class.name: Pixel_Dimensions
DD_Class.definition: The Pixel_Dimensions class contains information regarding pixel size.

DD_Class.name: Pixel_Intercept
DD_Class.definition: The Pixel_Intercept class provides the latitude and longitude on the surface of the target for the projection of the specificed pixel. The pixel is specfied using either reference_pixel_location or Reference_Pixel. Although each of these is optional, one must be used.

DD_Class.name: Footprint_Vertices
DD_Class.definition: The Footprint_Vertices class provides a set of associations between pixels and their projections on the target. The pixels should be choose to be the vertices of a polygon, plotted sequenually in a the direction.

DD_Class.name: Surface_Geometry
DD_Class.definition: The Surface_Geometry class contains classes and attributes for various points of the surface of the target designated in the enclosing Geometry_Orbiter.

DD_Class.name: Illumination_Geometry
DD_Class.definition: The Illumination_Geometry class contains two optional classes used to describing the field of view lighting.

DD_Class.name: Image_Display_Geometry
DD_Class.definition: Image_Display_Geometry class provides an unambiguous description of the orientation of the image contents. Given an image, displayed as described by the Display_Direction class, any one of the Object_Orientation_* classes should allow unambiguous orientation of the contents of the image. The use of disp:Display_Direction is optional, but must be given either here or in the Display Discipline Area of the label. The Object_Orientation_North_East class is typically used for instruments for which the entire field of view is a portion of the target surface (e.g., instruments on Mars orbital spacecraft); otherwise use Object_Orientation_RA_Dec (e.g., flyby missions, missions with orbit radii much larger than the target radius such as Voyager or Cassini). At least one of these must be used.

DD_Class.name: Distance_Generic
DD_Class.definition: The distance between the two objects, both of which must be specified.

DD_Class.name: Distances
DD_Class.definition: The Distances class is a container class for distances.

DD_Class.name: Position_Vector_Cartesian_Base
DD_Class.definition: The Position_Vector_Cartesian_Base is a three dimensional, rectangular coordinates vector. Uses units of length. The included attributes are not sufficient to identify the endpoints of the vector.

DD_Class.name: Position_Vector_Cartesian_Extended_Base
DD_Class.definition: The Position_Vector_Cartesian_Extended_Base is a three dimensional, rectangular coordinates vector. Uses units of length. The included attributes are not sufficient to identify the endpoints of the vector. While the attribute Coordinate_System is optional, it must be used here if the coordinate system has not been specified in the enclosing class.

DD_Class.name: Velocity_Vector_Cartesian_Base
DD_Class.definition: The Velocity_Vector_Cartesian_Base is a three dimensional, rectangular coordinates vector. Uses units of linear velocity. The included attributes are not sufficient to identify the endpoints of the vector.

DD_Class.name: Velocity_Vector_Cartesian_Extended_Base
DD_Class.definition: The Velocity_Vector_Cartesian_Extended_Base is a three dimensional, rectangular coordinates vector. Uses units of linear velocity. The included attributes are not sufficient to identify the endpoints of the vector. While the attribute Coordinate_System is optional, it must be used here if the coordinate system has not been specified in the enclosing class.

DD_Class.name: Acceleration_Vector_Cartesian_Base
DD_Class.definition: The Acceleration_Vector_Cartesian_Base is a three dimensional, rectangular coordinates vector. Uses units of linear acceleration. The included attributes are not sufficient to identify the endpoints of the vector.

DD_Class.name: Acceleration_Vector_Cartesian_Extended_Base
DD_Class.definition: The Acceleration_Vector_Cartesian_Extended_Base is a three dimensional, rectangular coordinates vector. Uses units of linear acceleration. The included attributes are not sufficient to identify the endpoints of the vector. While the attribute Coordinate_System is optional, it must be used here if the coordinate system has not been specified in the enclosing class.

DD_Class.name: Position_Vector_Planetocentric_Base
DD_Class.definition: The Position_Vector_Planetocentric_Base is a three dimensional spherical vector (radius, longitude, latitude) with the angular coordinates defined to be consistent with the Planetocentric coordinate system. Uses linear units for the radius dimension, and angular units for the other two dimensions. The included attributes are not sufficient to identify the endpoints of the vector.

DD_Class.name: Position_Vector_Planetocentric_Extended_Base
DD_Class.definition: The Position_Vector_Planetocentric_Extended_Base is a three dimensional spherical vector (radius, longitude, latitude) with the angular coordinates defined to be consistent with the Planetocentric coordinate system. Uses linear units for the radius dimension, and angular units for the other two dimensions. The included attributes are not sufficient to identify the endpoints of the vector. While the attribute Coordinate_System is optional, it must be used here if the coordinate system has not been specified in the enclosing class.

DD_Class.name: Velocity_Vector_Planetocentric_Base
DD_Class.definition: The Velocity_Vector_Planetocentric_Base is a three dimensional spherical vector (radius, longitude, latitude) with the angular coordinates defined to be consistent with the Planetocentric coordinate system. Uses linear velocity units for the radius dimension, and angular velocity units for the other two dimensions. The included attributes are not sufficient to identify the endpoints of the vector. While the attribute Coordinate_System is optional, if it is appropriate for this vector, it must be used here if the coordinate system has not been specified in the Geometry_Orbiter class.

DD_Class.name: Velocity_Vector_Planetocentric_Extended_Base
DD_Class.definition: The Velocity_Vector_Planetocentric_Extended_Base is a three dimensional spherical vector (radius, longitude, latitude) with the angular coordinates defined to be consistent with the Planetocentric coordinate system. Uses linear velocity units for the radius dimension, and angular velocity units for the other two dimensions. The included attributes are not sufficient to identify the endpoints of the vector. While the attribute Coordinate_System is optional, it must be used here if the coordinate system has not been specified in the enclosing class.

DD_Class.name: Vector_Cartesian_Unit
DD_Class.definition: This is a generic unit vector in Cartesian space. The "x", "y", and "z" component have no units and are restricted to values between -1.0 and 1.0 inclusive. Further the length of the vector square root of the (sum of the squares of the components) must be 1.0.

DD_Class.name: Vector_Cartesian_No_Units
DD_Class.definition: This is a generic vector in Cartesian space. The "x", "y", and "z" component have no units.

DD_Class.name: Vector_Cartesian_Pixel
DD_Class.definition: This a Cartesian pixel vector generally used in camera models.

DD_Class.name: Position_Vector_Cartesian_Generic
DD_Class.definition: Position_Vector_Cartesian_Generic is a three dimensional, rectangular coordinates vector. Uses units of length. Includes attributes to identify the endpoints of the vector.

DD_Class.name: Velocity_Vector_Cartesian_Generic
DD_Class.definition: Velocity_Vector_Cartesian_Generic is a three dimensional, rectangular coordinates vector. Uses units of linear velocity. Includes attributes to identify the endpoints of the vector.

DD_Class.name: Acceleration_Vector_Cartesian_Generic
DD_Class.definition: Acceleration_Vector_Cartesian_Generic is a three dimensional, rectangular coordinates vector. Uses units of linear acceleration. Includes attributes to identify the endpoints of the vector.

DD_Class.name: Position_Vector_Planetocentric_Generic
DD_Class.definition: The Position_Vector_Planetocentric_Generic is a three dimensional spherical vector (radius, longitude, latitude) with the angular coordinates defined to be consistent with the Planetocentric coordinate system. Uses linear units for the radius dimension, and angular units for the other two dimensions. Includes attributes to identify the endpoints of the vector.

DD_Class.name: Velocity_Vector_Planetocentric_Generic
DD_Class.definition: The Velocity_Vector_Planetocentric_Generic is a three dimensional spherical vector (radius, longitude, latitude) with the angular coordinates defined to be consistent with the Planetocentric coordinate system. Uses linear velocity units for the radius dimension, and angular velocity units for the other two dimensions. Includes attributes to identify the endpoints of the vector.

DD_Class.name: Central_Body_To_Spacecraft_Position_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The Central_Body_To_Spacecraft_Position_Vector_Cartesian is a linear, rectangular coordinates vector from the center of mass of the central body (e.g., planet) to the spacecraft.

DD_Class.name: Central_Body_To_Target_Position_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The Central_Body_To_Target_Position_Vector_Cartesian is a linear, rectangular coordinates vector from the center of mass of the central body (e.g., planet) to the target specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class.

DD_Class.name: Spacecraft_To_Target_Position_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The Spacecraft_To_Target_Position_Vector_Cartesian is a linear, rectangular coordinates vector from the spacecraft to the target specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class.

DD_Class.name: Central_Body_To_Spacecraft_Position_Vector_Planetocentric
DD_Class.definition: The Central_Body_To_Spacecraft_Position_Vector_Planetocentric is a spherical position vector in Planetocentric coordinates. It extends from the center of mass of the central body (e.g., planet) to the spacecraft.

DD_Class.name: Central_Body_To_Target_Position_Vector_Planetocentric
DD_Class.definition: The Central_Body_To_Target_Position_Vector_Planetocentric is a spherical position vector in Planetocentric coordinates. It extends from the center of mass of the central body (e.g., planet) to the target specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class.

DD_Class.name: Spacecraft_To_Target_Position_Vector_Planetocentric
DD_Class.definition: The Spacecraft_To_Target_Position_Vector_Planetocentric is a spherical position vector in Planetocentric coordinates. It extends from the spacecraft to the target specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class..

DD_Class.name: SSB_To_Central_Body_Position_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The SSB_To_Central_Body_Position_Vector_Cartesian is a linear, rectangular coordinates vector from the Solar System Barycenter to the central body (e.g., planet).

DD_Class.name: SSB_To_Spacecraft_Position_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The SSB_To_Spacecraft_Position_Vector_Cartesian is a linear, rectangular coordinates vector from the Solar System Barycenter to the spacecraft.

DD_Class.name: SSB_To_Target_Position_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The SSB_To_Target_Position_Vector_Cartesian is a linear, rectangular coordinates vector from the Solar System Barycenter to the target specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class.

DD_Class.name: Sun_To_Central_Body_Position_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The Sun_To_Central_Body_Position_Vector_Cartesian is a linear, rectangular coordinates vector from the Sun to the central body (e.g., planet).

DD_Class.name: Sun_To_Spacecraft_Position_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The Sun_To_Spacecraft_Position_Vector_Cartesian is a linear, rectangular coordinates vector from the Sun to the spacecraft.

DD_Class.name: Sun_To_Target_Position_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The Sun_To_Target_Position_Vector_Cartesian is a linear, rectangular coordinates vector from the Sun to the target specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class.

DD_Class.name: Earth_To_Central_Body_Position_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The Earth_To_Central_Body_Position_Vector_Cartesian is a linear, rectangular coordinates vector from the Earth to the central body (e.g., planet).

DD_Class.name: Earth_To_Spacecraft_Position_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The Earth_To_Spacecraft_Position_Vector_Cartesian is a linear, rectangular coordinates vector from the Earth to the spacecraft.

DD_Class.name: Earth_To_Target_Position_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The Earth_To_Target_Position_Vector_Cartesian is a linear, rectangular coordinates vector from the Earth to the target specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class.

DD_Class.name: Spacecraft_Relative_To_Central_Body_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The Spacecraft_Relative_To_Central_Body_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian is a velocity vector in rectangular coordinates that gives the velocity of the spacecraft with respect to the central body (e.g., planet).

DD_Class.name: Spacecraft_Relative_To_Target_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The Spacecraft_Relative_To_Target_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian is a velocity vector in rectangular coordinates that gives the velocity of the spacecraft with respect to the target specified in the parent Geometry_Orbiter class.

DD_Class.name: Spacecraft_Relative_To_Earth_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The Spacecraft_Relative_To_Earth_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian is a velocity vector in rectangular coordinates that gives the velocity of the spacecraft with respect to Earth.

DD_Class.name: Spacecraft_Relative_To_SSB_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The Spacecraft_Relative_To_SSB_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian is a velocity vector in rectangular coordinates that gives the velocity of the spacecraft with respect to the Solar System Barycenter.

DD_Class.name: Spacecraft_Relative_To_Sun_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: Spacecraft_Relative_To_Sun_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian is a velocity vector in rectangular coordinates that gives the velocity of the spacecraft with respect to the center of the Sun.

DD_Class.name: Target_Relative_To_Central_Body_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The Target_Relative_To_Central_Body_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian is a velocity vector in rectangular coordinates that gives the velocity of the designated target with respect to the central body (e.g., planet).

DD_Class.name: Target_Relative_To_Spacecraft_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The Target_Relative_To_Spacecraft_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian is a velocity vector in rectangular coordinates that gives the velocity of the designated target with respect to the spacecraft.

DD_Class.name: Target_Relative_To_Earth_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The Target_Relative_To_Earth_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian is a velocity vector in rectangular coordinates that gives the velocity of the designated target with respect to Earth.

DD_Class.name: Target_Relative_To_SSB_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: The Target_Relative_To_SSB_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian is a velocity vector in rectangular coordinates that gives the velocity of the designated target with respect to the Solar System Barycenter.

DD_Class.name: Target_Relative_To_Sun_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian
DD_Class.definition: Target_Relative_To_Sun_Velocity_Vector_Cartesian is a velocity vector in rectangular coordinates that gives the velocity of the designated target with respect to the center of the sun.

DD_Class.name: Spacecraft_Relative_To_Target_Velocity_Vector_Planetocentric
DD_Class.definition: The Spacecraft_Relative_To_Target_Velocity_Vector_Planetocentric is a spherical velocity vector in Planetocentric coordinates that gives the velocity of the spacecraft with respect to the designated target.

DD_Class.name: Target_Relative_To_Central_Body_Velocity_Vector_Planetocentric
DD_Class.definition: The Target_Relative_To_Central_Body_Velocity_Vector_Planetocentric is a spherical velocity vector in Planetocentric coordinates that gives the velocity of the target with respect to the central body.

DD_Class.name: Target_Relative_To_Spacecraft_Velocity_Vector_Planetocentric
DD_Class.definition: The Target_Relative_To_Spacecraft_Velocity_Vector_Planetocentric is a spherical velocity vector in Planetocentric coordinates that gives the velocity of the target with respect to the spacecraft.

DD_Class.name: Specific_Position_Vectors
DD_Class.definition: The Specific_Position_Vectors class is a container class for all position vectors with pre-identified endpoints.

DD_Class.name: Specific_Velocity_Vectors
DD_Class.definition: The Specific_Velocity_Vectors class is a container class for all velocity vectors with pre-identified endpoints.

DD_Class.name: Specific_Cartesian_Vectors
DD_Class.definition: The Specific_Cartesian_Vectors class is a container class for all cartesian vectors with pre-identified endpoints.

DD_Class.name: Specific_Planetocentric_Vectors
DD_Class.definition: The Specific_Planetocentric_Vectors class is a container class for all planetocentric vectors with pre-identified endpoints.

DD_Class.name: Generic_Vectors
DD_Class.definition: The Generic_Vectors class is a container class for all of the build your own vector templates.

DD_Class.name: Geometry_Orbiter
DD_Class.definition: The Geometry_Orbiter class is a container for geometric information (positions, velocities, orientations, etc.) relevant to orbiter or flyby spacecraft observations.

DD_Class.name: Device_Angle_Index
DD_Class.definition: TBD

DD_Class.name: Device_Angle
DD_Class.definition: TBD

DD_Class.name: Device_Component_State_Index
DD_Class.definition: TBD

DD_Class.name: Device_Component_State
DD_Class.definition: TBD

DD_Class.name: Device_Motor_Clicks_Index
DD_Class.definition: TBD

DD_Class.name: Device_Motor_Clicks
DD_Class.definition: TBD

DD_Class.name: Device_Orientation_Quaternion
DD_Class.definition: TBD

DD_Class.name: Device_Position_Vector
DD_Class.definition: TBD

DD_Class.name: Device_Temperature_Index
DD_Class.definition: TBD

DD_Class.name: Device_Temperature
DD_Class.definition: TBD

DD_Class.name: Axis_Vector
DD_Class.definition: The Axis_Vector describes the axis of the camera, defined as the normal to the image plane.

DD_Class.name: Center_Vector
DD_Class.definition: The Center_Vector describes the location of the pinhole of a camera.

DD_Class.name: Horizontal_Vector
DD_Class.definition: The Horizontal_Vector encodes the horizontal axis of the image plane (H'), the coordinate (Hc) of the image column at the optical centre of the image plane, and the horizontal focal length (Hs) of the camera, in pixels.

DD_Class.name: Vertical_Vector
DD_Class.definition: The Vertical_Vector encodes the vertical axis of the image plane (V' or Vp), the coordinate (Vc) of the image row(?) at the optical centre of the image plane, and the vertical focal length (Vs) of the camera, in pixels.

DD_Class.name: Optical_Terms
DD_Class.definition: The Optical_Terms provides the optical axis coefficients used for lens-distortion correction when the distortion is radial.

DD_Class.name: Radial_Terms
DD_Class.definition: The Radial_Vector provides the radial lens distortion coefficients defined in the ground (object) coordinate system.

DD_Class.name: Entrance_Vector
DD_Class.definition: The Entrance_Vector describes the location of the entrance pupil of a camera.

DD_Class.name: CAHV_Model
DD_Class.definition:
The CAHV camera model is equivalent to the standard linear photogrammetric model for a pinhole camera, It is useful for very small field of view cameras and as a building block for more complex camera models.
The CAHV model consists of four 3-vectors: C, A, H, and V.
Vector C gives the location of the pinhole.
Vector A gives the camera axis, defined as the normal to the image plane.
Vector H encodes the horizontal axis of the image plane (H'), the coor- dinate (Hc) of the image column at the optical centre of the image plane, and the horizontal focal length (Hs) of the camera, in pixels.
Vector V encodes corresponding information (V', Vc, Vs) in the vertical direction.
The angle (theta) between horizontal and vertical vectors H' and V' is about 90 degrees.
(Taken from Camera Response Simulation for Planetary Exploration, by Dr. Richard Madison, Marc Pomerantz, and Dr. Abhinandan Jain, http://trs-new.jpl.nasa.gov/dspace/bitstream/2014/37771/1/05-1692.pdf)

DD_Class.name: CAHVOR_Model
DD_Class.definition:
The CAHVOR model describes a camera with radial lens distortion about the lens axis. In addition to the CAHV parameters, it includes 3-vectors O and R. Vector O is the optical axis of the lens, slightly different from vector A due to imperfect lens mounting. A ray from a point in space, passing through the pinhole, bends at the pinhole according to a function of the angle between the ray and optical axis O. The function is a polynomial whose coefficients are stored in vector R.
(Taken from Camera Response Simulation for Planetary Exploration, by Dr. Richard Madison, Marc Pomerantz, and Dr. Abhinandan Jain, http://trs-new.jpl.nasa.gov/dspace/bitstream/2014/37771/1/05-1692.pdf)

DD_Class.name: CAHVORE_Model
DD_Class.definition:
A third model, CAHVORE, describes more general cameras including those with fisheye or otherwise wide field of view lenses. An additional vector, E, describes the apparent motion of the camera entrance pupil.
(Taken from Camera Response Simulation for Planetary Exploration, by Dr. Richard Madison, Marc Pomerantz, and Dr. Abhinandan Jain, http://trs-new.jpl.nasa.gov/dspace/bitstream/2014/37771/1/05-1692.pdf)

DD_Class.name: Present_Coordinate_Space
DD_Class.definition: TBD

DD_Class.name: Origin_Offset_Vector
DD_Class.definition: TBD

DD_Class.name: Rotation_Quaternion
DD_Class.definition: TBD

DD_Class.name: Motion_Counter_Index
DD_Class.definition: The Motion_Counter_Index class identifies and populates one element of a Motion_Counter list. The class should be repeated for each element of the list.

DD_Class.name: Articulation_Device_Parameters
DD_Class.definition: TBD

DD_Class.name: Camera_Model_Parameters
DD_Class.definition: A camera model describes the mathematical relationship between the coordinates of a point in 3-dimensional space and its projection onto a 2-dimensional image plane. There are numerous types of camera models, only two of which are currently implemented.

DD_Class.name: Coordinate_Space_Definition
DD_Class.definition: TBD.

DD_Class.name: Derived_Geometry
DD_Class.definition: Includes stuff like inst/solar az/el, distances, etc. relative to a single specified reference frame or coordinate space

DD_Class.name: Motion_Counter
DD_Class.definition: The Motion_Counter class provides a set of integers which describe a (potentially) unique location (position / orientation) for a rover or other movable object. Each time an event occurs that results in a movement, a new motion counter value is created. This includes intentional motion due to drive commands, as well as potential motion due to other articulating devices, such as arms or antennae. This motion counter (or part of it) is used as a reference to define instances of coordinate systems which can move such as SITE or ROVER frames. The motion counter is defined in a mission-specific manner. Although the original intent was to have incrementing indices (e.g., MER), the motion counter could also contain any integer values which conform to the above definition, such as time or spacecraft clock values.

DD_Class.name: Geometry_Lander
DD_Class.definition: The Geometry_Lander class is a container for all geometric information in the label relating to a landed spacecraft, including rovers.

DD_Class.name: Geometry
DD_Class.definition: The Geometry class is a container for all geometric information in the label.
